Ok this is a duplicate post, but with further sugestions.

The idea that you have produced Cu(OH)2 is a little misleading is it not? The reason for the variation in colour is that various basic copper sulphates/hydroxide minerals are formed in different ratios depending on exactly how they are mixed.
Spertiniite Cu(OH)2
Antlerite Cu3(SO4)(OH)4
Brochantite Cu4SO4(OH)6

Could you test for the presence of sulphate after reprecipitating the cellulose in hydrochloric or nitric ( or acetic or citric ) acid?

Why would you dissolve cellulose? What it is used for?

You say that, to make paper, clothing and cellophane, cellulose must first be dissolved.  This is wrong.  Cellulose is not dissolved in any of these processes.  To make paper, cellulose fibers are separated from the non-cellulose components of the starting material, then the cellulose is suspended, not dissolved, in water and cast into a sheet by mechanical filtration.  To make clothing, cotton fibers, made of cellulose, are mechanically separated from other parts of the cotton boll.  No dissolving is involved.

Antlerite (CuSO4·2Cu(OH)2) and brochantite (CuSO4·3Cu(OH)2
are basic copper sulphates that are usually green

Using a bit different chemicals this is the principle to turn wood fibre into rayon that you make fabric and clothing from. You dissolve the fibres into sodium hydroxide and carbon disulfide. Upon pumping the solution trough fine nozzles submerged in a tank of sulphuric acid and some other add on chemicals rayon fibres are formed and then spooled up.
